The Business Value of APIs

  5. Focus on Products and Landscape [4]

The Business Value of APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): API Standards: Balancing Chaos and Rigidity

(6) API Products: Reduce Time-to-Value

  • Build better products faster because they're not built from scratch
  • Focus on differentiators and reuse building blocks for the rest
    • Build the building blocks you were hoping to find but didn't


The Business Value of APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): API Standards: Balancing Chaos and Rigidity

(7) API Landscapes: Increase Collaboration & Innovation

  • Organization size increases the collaboration/reuse paradox
    • More potential for reuse but harder to do it effectively
  • APIs are the digital building blocks for creating/enriching value chains
  • In a platform world, every consumer of a platform contributes to it
    • API first means that every product is built with an API mindset
    • Using APIs means that the (re-)used APIs become more valuable


Standards: A Brief Introduction

Outline (Standards: A Brief Introduction)

Standards: A Brief Introduction Erik Wilde (@dret): API Standards: Balancing Chaos and Rigidity

(9) Three Standards Value Propositions

  1. Provide a stable foundation and out-of-the-box interoperability
  2. Provide stable building blocks for a shorter time-to-value
  3. Reduce dependency risk because you can more easily switch suppliers


Standards: A Brief Introduction Erik Wilde (@dret): API Standards: Balancing Chaos and Rigidity

(10) Standards are a Foundation



Standards: A Brief Introduction Erik Wilde (@dret): API Standards: Balancing Chaos and Rigidity

(11) Standards are Building Blocks



Standards: A Brief Introduction Erik Wilde (@dret): API Standards: Balancing Chaos and Rigidity

(12) Value vs. Effort/Risk



How Standards Mature

Outline (How Standards Mature)

  1. Introduction [2]
  2. The Business Value of APIs [2]
  3. Standards: A Brief Introduction [4]
  4. How Standards Mature [5]
  5. Focus on Products and Landscape [4]
  6. Conclusions [2]
How Standards Mature Erik Wilde (@dret): API Standards: Balancing Chaos and Rigidity

(14) 1. Patterns

  • The same design questions have to be addressed in many APIs
  • It becomes apparent that these are necessary but not sufficient
    • They are necessary because these issues need to be addressed
    • They are not sufficient because it's not how value is created


How Standards Mature Erik Wilde (@dret): API Standards: Balancing Chaos and Rigidity

(15) 2. Personal Standards

  • Addressing 1. Patterns [1. Patterns (1)] more effectively by reusing design elements
  • Helps with surfacing we all seem to address the same issue realizations
  • Increases personal efficiency but is ineffective for the organization


How Standards Mature Erik Wilde (@dret): API Standards: Balancing Chaos and Rigidity

(16) 3. Organizational Standards

  • Creating consistency across organizational APIs
    • Less effort for API designers (focus on core design questions)
    • Less effort for API consumers (coherence across the API landscape)
  • API Design Guidelines [https://dret.github.io/guidelines/] are a well-known pattern
    • Guidelines should be participatory and constantly evolving


How Standards Mature Erik Wilde (@dret): API Standards: Balancing Chaos and Rigidity

(17) 4. Vertical Standards

  • Domain-specific standards may emerge
    • Many of these are monolithic and have interoperability in mind
    • Focusing more on building blocks could make efforts more effective
  • Most often driven by consortia and their member organizations


How Standards Mature Erik Wilde (@dret): API Standards: Balancing Chaos and Rigidity

(18) 5. Global Standards

  • Global standards body for cross-domain building blocks
  • High threshold and potentially time-consuming process
  • Best chance for tooling and other standards to evolve
    • Stable building blocks provide the best foundation


Focus on Products and Landscape

Outline (Focus on Products and Landscape)

  1. Introduction [2]
  2. The Business Value of APIs [2]
  3. Standards: A Brief Introduction [4]
  4. How Standards Mature [5]
  5. Focus on Products and Landscape [4]
  6. Conclusions [2]
Focus on Products and Landscape Erik Wilde (@dret): API Standards: Balancing Chaos and Rigidity

(20) Product Focus: Reduce Time-to-Value

  • Make it easier to create products by not re-inventing wheels
  • The ideal product development process:
    • Identify markets and create designs matching the needs
    • Evaluate the difference between platform capabilities and product needs
    • Enrich the platform while working on delivering the product


Focus on Products and Landscape Erik Wilde (@dret): API Standards: Balancing Chaos and Rigidity

(21) Landscape Focus: Optimize Landscape Value

  • Make it easy to produce, find, and use wheels
  • The ideal platform management process:
    • Make it easy for product teams to find meaningful digital building blocks
    • Help with building block identification and production
    • Continuously improve the platform by providing support and tooling


Focus on Products and Landscape Erik Wilde (@dret): API Standards: Balancing Chaos and Rigidity

(22) Some Examples

  • HTTP Problem Reports (RFC 7807 [https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7807] which is being revised [https://github.com/ietf-wg-httpapi/rfc7807bis])
  • HTTP API Health Check Response Format [https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-inadarei-api-health-check]
  • HTTP header fields for managing the API lifecycle [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=twfufQn1mD0]
    • Deprecation for signaling API deprecation (under development [https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-httpapi-deprecation-header])
    • Sunset for signaling API shutdown (RFC 8594 [https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc8594])


Focus on Products and Landscape Erik Wilde (@dret): API Standards: Balancing Chaos and Rigidity

(23) What's in it for me?

  • Standards help with making API landscapes more effective
    • Formal standards allow to rely on ready-made building blocks
    • Informal standards provide a good way to elicit building blocks
  • APIs and platforms work better with a clear business focus [https://hbr.org/2021/04/apis-arent-just-for-tech-companies]
    • Platform business models [https://www.applicoinc.com/blog/what-is-a-platform-business-model/] take a structured view of value chains and contributions
    • Tech/biz alignment result in a more business-focused view of building block value


Conclusions

Outline (Conclusions)

Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): API Standards: Balancing Chaos and Rigidity

(25) Treat Standards Strategically

  • Have a designated standards person in your organization
    • Follow activities of the usual suspects (IETF, W3C) and of select communities
    • For bonus points, actively participate and contribute to the API community
  • Track which standards are being used and which standards are needed
    • Use Web Concepts [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zoBdIyMznDs] or a similar approach for tracking standards use
    • Keep a backlog of areas where standards would be good to have
    • Have regular standards updates about new used standards and ongoing initiatives
  • Rough Consensus and Running Code [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rough_consensus] is a good mantra to follow


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): API Standards: Balancing Chaos and Rigidity
